snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday's selection includes the kinds of things people like to read about online, crowdfunding as a possible avenue for financing things l...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Thursday's selection includes the kinds of things people like to read about online, crowdfunding as a possible avenue for financing things like biotechnology and clean energy, and a Twitter feed that posts descriptions of Instagram photos but no photos.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Silicon Valley Sexism, and Apple After Jobs

snippet: The Consumer Federation of America and Public Knowledge, opponents of the Universal Music Group's $1.9 billion bid for EMI's record labels, are asking the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust issues to examine the deal.
abstract: The Consumer Federation of America and Public Knowledge, opponents of the Universal Music Group's $1.9 billion bid for EMI's record labels, are asking the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust issues to examine the deal.

headline.main: Groups Seek Senate Review of Universal-EMI Deal

headline.main: Spare Times: For Children, for April 27 — May 3

snippet: Amazon.com’s net income dropped 35 percent in the first quarter as the company spent on its Kindle Fire and other projects, but earnings still beat Wall Street’s expectations.
abstract: Amazon.com reports a 35 percent drop in net income, but still manages to exceed Wall Street expectations; company reports net income of $130 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with $201 million, or 44 cents a share, in the same period a year ago; Amazon’s revenue rose 34 percent to $13.18 billion from $9.86 billion a year ago.

headline.main: Amazon’s Earnings Decline 35% but Top Forecasts
headline.print_headline: Amazon’s Earnings Decline 35% but Top Forecasts

snippet: In his second day of testimony during a British inquiry into media ethics, he predicts that newspapers will exist as print versions for 20 more years, but with very small circulations.
abstract: In his second day of testimony during a British inquiry into media ethics, he predicts that newspapers will exist as print versions for 20 more years, but with very small circulations.

headline.main: Rupert Murdoch on the Future of News

snippet: O.K., software industry, you've been put on notice: Nowadays, there's more to it than design, features and marketing. Sometimes, the success of your app can ride on the wording and placement of a single dialog box.
abstract: O.K., software industry, you've been put on notice: Nowadays, there's more to it than design, features and marketing. Sometimes, the success of your app can ride on the wording and placement of a single dialog box.

snippet: Lockheed Martin, Starwood Hotels and Amazon posted encouraging results, while those from Dow Chemical and UPS pointed to looming problems in Europe.
abstract: Stocks rise as Wall Street is encouraged by stronger earnings reports and hopeful news about home sales.
